name: New Zealand
description: New Zealand, known as Aotearoa in Māori, is an island nation in the southwestern Pacific Ocean. Comprising two main landmasses, the North Island (Te Ika-a-Māui) and the South Island (Te Waipounamu), it’s renowned for its dramatic landscapes, including towering mountains, active volcanoes, geothermal areas, glaciers, and extensive coastlines. The country boasts a unique biodiversity, shaped by its isolation and diverse environments, and is a popular destination for adventure tourism and nature enthusiasts.

quickFacts.label: Population
quickFacts.description: New Zealand has a relatively small but vibrant population.
quickFacts.detail: The population is concentrated along the coastlines of both islands.

quickFacts.label: Capital
quickFacts.description: Wellington is the political and administrative center of New Zealand.
quickFacts.detail: It’s situated on the southern tip of the North Island.

quickFacts.label: Official Languages
quickFacts.value: English, Māori, and New Zealand Sign Language
quickFacts.description: Māori is the indigenous language and holds significant cultural importance.
quickFacts.detail: English is the most widely spoken language for business and daily life.

quickFacts.label: Currency
quickFacts.description: The NZD is pegged to the Australian dollar.
quickFacts.detail: It's a stable and reliable currency.

quickFacts.label: Time Zone
quickFacts.description: New Zealand operates on a single time zone.
quickFacts.detail: It’s ahead of many other countries.

climateData.title: New Zealand Climate
climateData.description: New Zealand experiences a temperate maritime climate, influenced by the surrounding ocean currents. Temperatures vary significantly between the North and South Islands, with the North Island generally warmer and more humid, and the South Island cooler and drier.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Summer (December - February)
seasonalCharacteristics.description: Summer is the peak tourist season, with warm temperatures and plenty of sunshine. It's ideal for outdoor activities.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Autumn (March - May)
seasonalCharacteristics.description: Autumn brings cooler temperatures and stunning foliage displays, particularly in the South Island.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Winter (June - August)
seasonalCharacteristics.description: Winter is the wettest season, with cooler temperatures and occasional snowfall in the mountains. It's a good time for skiing and snowboarding.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Spring (September - November)
seasonalCharacteristics.description: Spring brings a burst of wildflowers and pleasant temperatures, marking the beginning of the tourist season.

naturalWonders.name: Fiordland National Park
naturalWonders.description: Fiordland is a UNESCO World Heritage site renowned for its dramatic fiords, towering waterfalls, and ancient rainforests. It’s a haven for wildlife and offers unparalleled opportunities for kayaking and hiking.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: The park encompasses Milford Sound, Doubtful Sound, and numerous other fiords carved by glaciers during the last ice age. The sheer scale and beauty of the landscape are truly awe-inspiring.
viewingTips: Book cruises and kayaking tours in advance

naturalWonders.name: Tongariro National Park
naturalWonders.description: Tongariro National Park is a volcanic wonderland, home to active volcanoes, geothermal areas, and stunning alpine landscapes. It’s famous for its three volcanic peaks – Ngauruhoe, Tongariro, and Ruapehu.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: The park is a popular destination for hiking, particularly the Tongariro Alpine Crossing, one of New Zealand’s most iconic day hikes. The volcanic terrain creates a surreal and otherworldly atmosphere.

naturalWonders.name: Abel Tasman National Park
naturalWonders.description: Abel Tasman National Park is a coastal paradise, characterized by golden beaches, turquoise waters, and lush native forests. It’s a popular destination for kayaking, hiking, and wildlife viewing.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: The park is accessible by boat, kayak, or on foot, offering a variety of ways to explore its stunning coastline. The sheltered bays and clear waters are perfect for swimming and snorkeling.
viewingTips: Rent a kayak or join a guided tour
Look out for seals and dolphins
Enjoy a picnic on the beach

ecosystemData.title: New Zealand Ecosystems
ecosystemData.overview: New Zealand boasts a remarkable array of ecosystems, shaped by its unique geological history and isolation. These include temperate rainforests, alpine meadows, volcanic landscapes, and extensive coastal areas, each supporting a diverse range of flora and fauna.

biodiversityCategories.name: Native Birds
biodiversityCategories.description: New Zealand is renowned for its unique native birdlife, many of which are found nowhere else in the world.

statistics.details: 80% of New Zealand’s bird species are endemic.
Over 30 bird species are currently threatened.

notableSpecies.name: Kiwi
notableSpecies.significance: National icon and a symbol of New Zealand's unique biodiversity.

notableSpecies.name: Kea
notableSpecies.significance: Highly intelligent and playful alpine parrot.

biodiversityCategories.name: Native Plants
biodiversityCategories.description: New Zealand’s native flora is incredibly diverse, adapted to a wide range of environments.

statistics.details: 90% of New Zealand’s native plant species are endemic.
Over 15 plant species are currently threatened.

notableSpecies.name: Kauri
notableSpecies.significance: One of the largest trees in the world, a keystone species in the rainforest.

notableSpecies.name: Rimu
notableSpecies.significance: A majestic tree with distinctive bark and cones.

activities.description: New Zealand offers a vast array of outdoor activities for all levels of experience, from gentle walks to challenging climbs.

activities.name: Abel Tasman Coast Track
activities.description: A scenic coastal track with stunning beaches and forests.

activityCategories.name: Water Sports
